paragraph.docTitle:
Phytochemistry and pharmacology of alkaloids from
Glaucium spp.

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O
Horn poppy
Aporphines
Benzylisoquinolines
Protopines
Benzophenanthridines
Glaucine
Acetylcholinesterase
A B S T R A C T

Glaucium Mill. comprising 28 species with 78 synonyms, 3 subspecies, and 3 varieties worldwide belongs to the Papaveraceae family. The plants are well known for their different types of alkaloids. In the present study, we attempted to review the chemistry and pharmacology of the alkaloids from the genus
Glaucium
. For this purpose, the relevant data were collected from different scientific databases including, “Google Scholar”, “ISI Web of Knowledge”, “PubMed”, “Scopus”, and available books and e-books. Our results showed that aporphine alkaloids are dominated in the species; however, other types of alkaloids including protopines, benzophenanthridines, benzylisoquinolines, protoberberines, and morphinanes have also been reported from the genus. The pharmacological studies have shown that the alkaloids from
Glaucium species
have several biological activities of which anti-cancer and anti-cholinesterase effects have been highly reported. Besides, the data indicated that most of the species have been investigated neither phytochemically nor pharmacologically.
Glaucium flavum
, known as yellow horn poppy, is the most studied species. According to the reports, the plants from this genus have anti-cancer and anti-cholinesterase potentials and can be used as a source for aporphine alkaloids.

Papaveraceae family is divided into three subfamilies: Chelidoniodeae, Eschscholzioideae, and Papaveroideae ( Kadereit, 1993 ; Kadereit et al., 1994 ; Tavakkoli and Assadi, 2019 ). The genus
Glaucium Mill. (Papaveraceae)
belongs to the latest subfamily and comprises two sections (sect. Acropetala Mory and sect.
Glaucium
) with 28 species (78 synonyms), 3 subspecies, and 3 varieties of the herbaceous annual, biennial, and perennial plants worldwide mostly distributed in Europe, Central and Southwest Asia (The plant list, 2013: http://www.theplantl ist.org/tpl1.1/search?q= Glaucium ; http://www.plantsoftheworldonl ine.org/?q=glauciu). The plants belonging to the genus
Glaucium ,
like other plants of the Papaveraceae family, contain different classes of alkaloids. However, the plants are well known for their aporphinoids including, isoquinoline alkaloids which are pharmacologically active ( Arafa et al., 2016 ). For instance, glaucine as a major aporphine alkaloid isolated from the species of the genus ( Nikolova et al., 2018 ), acts as a PDE4 inhibitor and calcium channel blocker. Besides, it has neuroleptic, bronchodilator, antitussive, and anti-inflammatory effects ( Scholar, 2007 ).

subSection.paragraph:
The relevant data were selected through scientific databases such as “Google Scholar”, “ISI Web of Knowledge”, “PubMed”, “ScienceDirect”, and “Wiley Online Library” using the keyword “
Glaucium
”. Information obtained in local and foreign books was also used to collect the information.

The genus
Glaucium (Papaveraceae)
consists of 28 species, 3 subspecies, and 3 varieties of the annual, biennial, or perennial herbaceous flowering plants worldwide ( Table 1 ). The plants are known as horned poppies because their pods are like horns. The plants are mostly native to Europe, North Africa, and southwest and central Asia.

Based on the literature review,
G. corniculatum
and
G. flavum
are the most reported species used in different folk and traditional systems of medicine. However, there should be a comprehensive study to investigate the medicinal applications of the species belonging to this genus around the world. Generally, the aerial parts and the seeds of the plants belonging to the genus
Glaucium
have been used as a narcotic, hypnotic, laxative, and anti-diabetic agent in the form of brew or decoction as well as in the treatment of dermatitis (Ibn Sin¯a, 1408; Ibn Beyṭ¯ar, 1422; Aquili Alawi Khorasani Shirazi, 2014 ).

Glaucium corniculatum
known as black-spot horned-poppy or red horned-poppy is called M¯amitha¯in Islamic traditional medicine (ITM) and has a cold and dry temperament in the first degree (Ibn Sina ¯, 1408; Ibn Beyṭar ¯, 1422). In ITM, the extract of
G. corniculatum
has been used to treat head and eye problems (in the form of kohl), edema, erysipelas, conjunctivitis, burns, and varicose veins (blepharitis). In addition, its external administration is believed to be useful for headaches, hot joint pain, early conjunctivitis, constipation (inflammation with ulcerative blepharitis), excess tearing, and drooping eyelids (Al-Qura’ n, 2009; Kocanci et al., 2017 ).
G. flavum
has been used in the form of decoction to relieve sciatica, liver disorders and is useful for people who have thick urine. A mixture of the seeds with honey has laxative properties and the ointment prepared from its leaves and flowers in olive oil is useful for treating late wounds (Ibn Sin¯a, 1408; Ibn Beyṭ¯ar, 1422). In Algeria ,
G. flavum
has been used to treat warts traditionally (Bournine et al., 2013a,b).

Table 2 summarizes the pharmacological activities reported for some species of the genus of
Glaucium
, including
G. acutidentatum
,
G. corniculatum
,
G. flavum , G. grandiflorum , G. oxylobum , G. paucilobum ,
and
G. vitellinum .
Most of the observed activities are related to the nervous system such as anti-AChE, analgesic, anti-nociceptive, neuroprotective, and anticonvulsant. However, antifungal, antibacterial, anti-diabetic, and anti-tumor activities have been also reported.

heading.emphasis:
6. Phytochemistry and pharmacology of
Glaucium
alkaloids

subSection.paragraph:
Although various specialized metabolites have been reported from
Glaucium
plants, alkaloids constitute the major active components of the species. Thus, the alkaloids present in these plants are discussed in the following paragraphs.

Different classes of alkaloids have been reported from the plants belonging to the genus
Glaucium
( Fig. 2 ). The alkaloids from the genus can be divided into six major categories: isoquinolines including aporphines, benzylisoquinolines, and protopines as well as benzophenanthridines, morphinanes, and protoberberines. However, the most common structural types are the isoquinoline derivatives ( Table 4 ). Isoquinoline alkaloids are natural products, which are chemically derived from isoquinoline ( Bisset, 1985 ) and form the largest group among the alkaloids. In the following paragraphs, the phytochemistry and pharmacology of the main alkaloids from the
Glaucium species
are discussed.
Table 1 ( continued )

subSection.paragraph:
Aporphine alkaloids constitute the major class of alkaloid metabolites in
Glaucium spp.
according to the literature ( Table 4 ). Depending upon the degree of methylation and oxidation at the nitrogen atom, the aporphine alkaloids in this genus can be divided into four groups: (a) the aporphines with an N-methyl function, (b) the noraporphines containing a secondary nitrogen atom, (c) the quaternary aporphine salts, and (d) N-oxide aporphines ( Shamma and Slusarchyk, 1964 ). From the pharmacological point of view, various health-related beneficial activities have been reported for the aporphine alkaloids. Glaucine, isoboldine, dicentrine, dehydrodicentrine, dicentrinone, domesticine, norbracteoline, corytuberine, and norcorydine are the most pharmacologically studied and active aporphine alkaloids in the genus
Glaucium
( Table 4 ).

6.1.1.1. Antitussive activity. Glaucine, first extracted from
G. flavum
, is a cough suppressant similar to codeine. In Eastern Europe, the hydrochloride and hydrobromide salts of its D-form have been used as cough suppressants. Synthetic glaucine is a racemic mixture with antitussive activity but without any significant activity on opioid receptors. Glaucine affects 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT) and dopamine receptors. Studies show that both R- and S-glaucine can act as antagonists of α1 receptors, but they behave very differently at 5-HT2 receptors. While Sglaucine is a partial agonist at all three 5-HT2 receptor subtypes, Rglaucine modulates only the 5-HT2 A receptor ( Heng et al., 2019 ).

6.1.1.2. Anti-cancer activity. Glaucine has also been reported to have cytotoxic, antiviral, and antioxidant activities. For instance, in an in vitro study on human breast cancer cells, glaucine could inhibit the invasion of cancerous cells via blocking MMP-9 expression and activity dose-dependently ( Kang et al., 2015 ). In another study, it was found that glaucine could inhibit MMP-9 expression by suppressing activation of the nuclear transcription factor NF-κB. Moreover, in two models of breast cancers, glaucine has been reported to have the ability to reverse the multi-drug resistance by inhibiting P-gp and BCRP. In addition, glaucine has exhibited synergistic effects with other cytotoxic drugs. For instance, glaucine (10 μM) could enhance the cytotoxicity of doxorubicin in Caco-2 and CEM ADR5000 cells 2.5–5.4 fold. In another study, glaucine could increase the cytotoxicity of mitoxantrone in MDA-MB-231 cancer cells, as a BCRP overexpressing breast cancer cell line, 2.5 fold and that of camptothecin 2.9-fold at 1 μM and 5 μM, respectively. It is worthy to mention that glaucine acts as a spasmolytic, adrenolytic, and antihydropic. Besides, its use is not associated with any dependency even after prolonged use. A feeling of sleepiness and tiredness, nausea, decreased blood pressure, and vomiting are the main side effects of glaucine. Moreover, glaucomatous visual hallucinations which are typical for hallucinogens have also been reported after glaucine consumption ( Geppert et al., 2010 ).

paragraph.tableNote: a The names and the authorities are according to theplantlist.org and the plantsoftheworldonline.org.

subSection.paragraph: Dicentrine exerts anti-inflammatory and anticancer activities and is a known α 1 -adrenoceptor antagonist. As an α 1 -adrenoceptor antagonist, dicentrine has been reported to be approximately 100 times more potent to the aortic contraction, than it was to the splenic contractions ( Mustafa and Achike, 2000 ).

subSection.paragraph: 6.1.2.1. Anti-cancer activity. In a study, dicentrine could potentiate apoptosis in a549 lung adenocarcinoma cells and suppressed the invasion of these cancerous cells via modulation of NF-κB and activation of activator protein-1 (AP-1) ( Ooppachai et al., 2019 ). In addition, it could increase caspase-8, -9, -3, and poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase activities, downregulate the invasive proteins, and significantly block TAK1, p38, JNK, and Akt, leading to a decrease in the transcriptional activity of NF-κB and AP-1 ( Ooppachai et al., 2019 ). In another study, dicentrine showed anti-proliferative activities on A 549, a human lung cancer cell line, by inducing apoptosis, increasing the number of cells in the S phase significantly ( P < 0.05), and activating caspase-3 ( Liu et al., 2011a ). In addition, studies show that dicentrine could significantly decrease telomerase activity by stabilizing G-quadruplex structure ( P < 0.05) ( Liu et al., 2011b ).

6.1.2.2. Anti-inflammatory activity. Regarding its anti-inflammatory activity, dicentrine could suppress inflammatory response through inhibiting NF-κB and AP-1 activation via blocking Akt and MAPKs signaling pathways in vitro ( Yodkeeree et al., 2018 ). The pre-treatment of macrophages with dicentrine suppressed pro-inflammatory cytokines and mediators including TNF-α, IL-6, prostaglandin E2, and NO . It showed inhibitory activity on the expression of inducible NO synthase and cyclooxygenase-2. It could inhibit the NF-κB activation by suppressing the phosphorylation of NF-κB at Ser536, reduce the phosphorylation and nucleus translocation of AP-1, and suppress the myeloid differentiation factor 88, Akt and MAPKs signaling pathway, which are the upstream signaling regulators of AP-1 and NF-κB ( Yodkeeree et al., 2018 ).

6.1.2.3. Anti-nociceptive activity. Anti-nociceptive effects have also been reported from dicentrine. For instance, oral administration of S- (+)-dicentrine ( 100 mg /kg) to mice could induce anti-nociceptive effects in acute and chronic inflammatory pain models ( Montrucchio et al., 2013 ). The anti-nociceptive activity of dicentrine has also been investigated by another research group ( Montrucchio et al., 2012 ). Administration of dicentrine ( 30–300 mg /kg) orally in mice could inhibit pain without causing changes in the motor performance dose-dependently ( Montrucchio et al., 2012 ).

6.1.2.4. Anticholinesterase activity. Dicentrine and its derivatives such as dehydrodicentrine have exhibited anti-AChE in few studies ( Dong et al., 2015 ). Studies show that dehydrodicentrine might be more potent than dicentrine. As an example, in a study using Ellman’ s AChE inhibition assay, dicentrine inhibited AChE activity with an IC 50 value of 93.5 μg/mL ( Kongkiatpaiboon et al., 2016 ) while in another study, dehydrodicentrine showed strong AChE inhibitory effects with the IC 50 value of 2.98 μM ( Dong et al., 2015 ).

6.1.2.5. Antiparasitic activity. Dicentrinone, another dicentrine derivative, showed a very potent leishmanicidal effect with IC 50 0.01 μM against promastigote forms of
Leishmania braziliensis
( Rasoanaivo et al., 1999 ; da Silva et al., 2009 ). This alkaloid also exhibited anti-parasitic activity against trypomastigote forms of
Trypanosoma cruzi
with IC 50 16.4 ± 1.7 μM, comparable to benznidazole (IC 50 18.7 ± 4.1 μM) as the positive control ( Barbosa et al., 2020 ).

Cytotoxic and anti-nociceptive activities have been reported for corytuberine, another bioactive constituent from
Glaucium species.
Corytuberine showed a cytotoxic effect against SMMC-7721 cell line (IC 50 values of 73.22 ± 2.35 M) ( Sun et al., 2014 ). In an animal model of study, administration of 6.3 and 12.5 mg /kg of (+)-corytuberine (i.p.) showed very potent anti-nociceptive effects in the writhing, hot plate, and the formalin tests ( Nishiyama et al., 2010 ).

A recent study introduced corydine as a new mu-opioid receptor (MOR) agonist. This compound could produce anti-nociceptive effects in mice after subcutaneous administration via a MOR-dependent mechanism. Furthermore, corydine was identified as G protein-biased agonists to the MOR without inducing β- arrestin2 recruitment upon receptor activation (Kaserer et al., 2020). Norcorydine has shown anti-parasitic activities (IC 50 1–10 μM) against multidrug-resistant strain K1 of
Plasmodium falciparum in vitro
( Wright et al., 2000 ).

Chelerythrine, (±)-chelidonine, dihydrochelerythrine, dihydrosanguinarine, ()-norchelidonine, sanguinarine are the most important benzophenanthridine alkaloids isolated from
Glaucium spp
( Table 4 ).

6.2.1.1. Anti-microbial activity. Chelerythrine in combination with sanguinarine has exerted anti-fungal and anti-biofilm activities against
Candida albicans
and
Cryptococcus neoformans
with MICs 2 and 16 μg/ mL, respectively. They could effectively inhibit biofilm formation of the pathogens at minimum biofilm inhibitory concentrations of 1 and 8 μg/ mL ( Qian et al., 2020 ). Disrupting the cell membrane and increasing the penetration of antibiotics into the fungal cells were proposed as two mechanisms for the antifungal mode of action ( Qian et al., 2020 ). In another study, chelerythrine has also exhibited antifungal activity against
C. albicans
with MICs ranged from 2 to 16 μg/ml. The mechanism was through inhibiting hyphal growth, increasing intracellular calcium levels, inducing accumulation of ROS, and inhibiting drug transporter activity ( Gong et al., 2020 ). Not only chelerythrine has exerted anti-fungal activities but also it has shown strong anti-bacterial effects. It showed potent antibacterial activities against Gram-positive bacteria,
Staphylococcus aureus
, Methicillin-resistant
S. aureus
, and extended spectrum β- lactamase
S. aureus
with MICs of 0.156 mg /mL in all three bacteria ( He et al., 2018 ). Interestingly, a few studies showed that this compound had inhibitory activity against plant pathogens. In a study, chelerythrine could inhibit
Ustilaginoidea virens
(50% EC 50 of 6.53 × 10
3 mg
/mL) and
Cochliobolus miyabeanus
(50% EC 50 of 5.62 × 10
3 mg
/mL), which are both rice plant pathogens. The best inhibitory activity was observed against
U. virens
at the concentration of 7.5 × 10
3 mg
/mL ( Wei et al., 2020 ).

6.2.1.2. Anti-cancer activity. Studies show that chelerythrine is an antineoplastic agent showing cytotoxic effects on various malignant cells. Chelerythrine chloride downregulated β- catenin implicating the downregulation of cancer stem cells transcription factors such as MYC and SOX2. Besides, it could inhibit soft agar colony-forming, invasion, migration, and spheroid forming abilities of stem cell properties in non-small cell lung carcinoma ( Heng and Cheah, 2020 ). Studies also showed that chelerythrine could induce apoptosis through ROS-mediated ER stress and STAT3 pathways in vitro ( He et al., 2020 ). Similarly, the results from another in vitro study showed that it could increase intracellular ROS leading to ER stress and cell apoptosis ( Wu et al., 2018 ).

caption.paragraph: Table 3 Anti-proliferative and cytotoxic activities of chelidonine.

subSection.paragraph: Studies show that dihydrosanguinarine has also potential anti-cancer activities through induction of apoptosis including mitochondrial membrane potential loss, increasing caspase-3 and -9 activities, cell cycle arrest at sub-G1, and loss of plasma membrane asymmetry ( Vrba et al., 2009 ). In a study, dihydrosanguinarine could regulate mut-p53/WT-p53 and the Ras/Raf/Mek/Erk pathway leading to the suppression of pancreatic cancer cells. Dihydrosanguinarine inhibited cell proliferation, migration, and invasion through cell cycle arrest and apoptosis ( Wu et al., 2019 ). However, Vrba et al. (2009) found that sanguinarine might be more potent than dihydrosanguinarine ( Vrba et al., 2009 ). In this in vitro model of study, sanguinarine with IC 50 0.9 μM (after 4h) showed more potency than dihydrosanguinarine with IC 50 20 μM (after 24 h).

6.2.2.2. Glucose uptake. Enhancing the glucose uptake is another activity reported for dihydrosanguinarine ( Chow et al., 2017 ). In mouse 3 T 3-L1 cells, dihydrosanguinarine could induce preadipocyte differentiation and lipid droplet accumulation through suppressing AMP-α, upregulating PPARγ expression and its target genes including Glut-4 and adiponectin, and reducing PPARγ phosphorylation ( Chow et al., 2017 ).

6.2.2.3. Anti-AChE activity. In a computational screening of some dietary phytochemicals in order to find potential anti-Alzheimer drugs, sanguinarine with some other natural compounds exhibited the most promising activities ( Amat-Ur-Rasool and Ahmed, 2015 ).

Chelidonine has not only been reported from the genus
Glaucium
, but also isolated from other plant species. It is a major alkaloid from
Chelidonium majus
, another member of the Papaveraceae family. There are a large number of papers reporting on the anti-inflammatory ( Liao et al., 2018 ; Zhang et al., 2018 ), anti-proliferative and anti-cancer activities of chelidonine. Table 3 summarizes some of the studies reporting the anti-tumor and anti-proliferative activities of this compound. In most of the studied cancerous cell lines, chelidonine could induce cell growth arrest mostly through apoptosis. Regarding the anti-inflammatory activities, chelidonine is reported to exhibit its beneficial effects through various mechanisms such as decreasing inflammatory mediators via inhibiting the TLR4/NF-κB signaling pathway, the NF-κB inflammatory pathways, and the expression of IL-4 and eotaxin-2 (O. Kim et al., 2015 ).

Protopines are metabolically derived from the benzylisoquinoline alkaloid ( S )-reticuline. Protopine is the prototype for this category of alkaloids and the most widely distributed one. That is why these types of alkaloids are known as protopines ( Guinaudeau and Shamma, 1982 ). Protopine is a histamine H 1 antagonist, an analgesic agent with opioid effects, and a platelet aggregation inhibitor. Besides, numerous biological effects including cardiovasoprotective, anti-inflammatory, anti-thrombotic, anti-inflammatory, neuroprotective, anti-spasmodic, anti-viral, anti-bacterial, anti-fungal, and anti-parasitic activities have been reported from different compounds of this alkaloid category ( Vacek et al., 2010 ). Fagarine, muramine, protopine, and dihydroprotopine are the reported protopine alkaloids from the genus
Glaucium
( Table 4 ).

Morphinan alkaloids are a large chemical class of psychoactive drugs, consisting of cough suppressants, opiate analgesics, and dissociative hallucinogens. Morphinans are the most powerful narcotic analgesics currently used for the treatment of moderate to severe chronic pains. Unlike the above-mentioned compound classes, morphinan-type alkaloids are not the major alkaloids in the genus
Glaucium
. Salutaridine is one of the most reported morphinans from the
Glaucium spp.
( Shafiee et al., 1979 ; Nikolova et al., 2018 ).

Tetrahydroprotoberberines, existing mainly in
Corydalis
and
Stephania spp.
, are able to target dopamine receptors including dopamine D1 and D2 families. This property makes them attractive candidates to treat neurological problems such as substance misuse ( Gadhiya et al., 2016 ). Tetrahydroprotoberberines share an isoquinoline structure consisting of a four-ring backbone, two of which are benzene rings situated on each end. They are classified into nonhydroxy, monohydroxy, and dihydroxy tetrahydroprotoberberines, based on the substitution of methoxyl or hydroxyl groups at C 2, C 3, C 9, C 10, and C 11 positions of the benzene rings ( Nesbit and Phillips, 2020 ). Scoulerine and isocorypalmine are two important tetrahydroprotoberberines reported from
Glaucium spp.

The genus
Glaucium
belonging to the Papaveraceae family mainly consists of alkaloids. Although aporphines, benzylisoquinolines, protopines, benzophenanthridines, morphinans, and protoberberines are the alkaloid classes reported from
Glaucium species
, aporphines are the dominated alkaloids in the genus. Glaucine and its derivatives with cytotoxic and antitussive activities, dicentrine and its derivatives including dehydrodicentrine and dicentrinone with anticancer, anti-inflammatory, antinociceptive, anti-AChE, and antiplasmodial activities, and corydine and its derivatives with anti-nociceptive and anti-parasitic activities are some major aporphines reported from the genus
Glaucium
. Chelerythrine, chelidonine, and sanguinarine are the most reported benzophenanthridines from the genus, with potent anticancer and anti-cholinesterase activities. Fagarine, muramine, protopine, and dihydroprotopine are the most reported protopine alkaloids from the genus
Glaucium
. Numerous biological effects including cardiovasoprotective, anti-inflammatory, anti-thrombotic, anti-inflammatory, neuroprotective, anti-spasmodic, anti-viral, antibacterial, anti-fungal, and anti-parasitic activities have been reported from different compounds of protopine alkaloids. Different tetrahydroprotoberberine alkaloids have been identified in
Glaucium spp.
As an example, scoulerine is one of the major ones with potent anti-cancer activities. Morphinan and benzylisoquinoline alkaloids are not dominated in the plants belonging to
Glaucium
plants. Taken together, the plants can be used as a rich source for the abovementioned alkaloids especially aporphines, protopines, and benzophenanthridines, with potent therapeutic activities particularly anticancer, anti-AChE, anti-BChE, and anti-parasitic effects.

subSection.paragraph: Toktam Akaberi (M.Sc.) is an organic chemist with a research focus on synthesis and semi-synthesis of natural products. She graduated in organic chemistry from Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, Iran . Her main research interest is semi-synthesis of nitrogen-bearing heterocyclic natural compounds.

Kamran Shourgashti (PharmD) recently graduated in pharmacy (2021) from Mashhad University of Medical Sciences, Iran . His PharmD thesis was isolation and identification of alkaloids from
Glaucium elegans Fisch.& C.A.Mey.
( Papaveraceae family).

Seyed Ahmad Emami (PharmD, PhD) graduated in pharmacy from Isfahan University of Medical Sciences (1993, Isfahan , Iran ) and received his PhD (2001) in Pharmacogosy from MUMS. He started his scientific works as a faculty member at MUMS in 2001 as an assistant professor and continued working as an associate professor from 2007 to 2012. Currently he is a full professor in Pharmacognosy (since 2012). His research is mainly on natural product based drug discovery, particularly according to the recommendations from traditional medicine.
Maryam Akaberi (M.Sc., Ph.D.) is a phytochemist, who completed a Ph.D. in Pharmacognosy at Mashhad University of
Medical Sciences (MUMS), Iran . She performed a post-doc by
Prof. Matthias Hamburger on HPLC-based activity profiling of some endemic Iranian plants (Pharmaceutical Biology,
Switzerland ). Currently, she is an assistant professor at the
Department of Pharmacognosy of the School of Pharmacy in
MUMS. She was awarded as the top student in the research of the school of pharmacy (MUMS) in 2016 and 2018 and the top student in the research of Razavi Khorasan Province ( Iran ) in
2019. Her Ph.D. thesis was awarded as the top research project in the 2nd Iranian Pharmacognosy Olympiad held in Isfahan ,

Iran (2019), and won the travel grant for the 67th annual meeting of GA held in Innsbruck, Austria (2019). Her main research interests focused on plant metabolomics, and molecular networking and the search for bioactive natural products, lead discovery, and extract/compound libraries. She is mainly involved in the development of dereplication and de-novo structure identification methods of natural products with LC techniques (LC-MS).
